0.00.text:
Translator: Linda Anderson
Reviewer: Rebecca DeHovitz

4.47.text:
So, I have a Facebook friend
whose life seems perfect.

9.39.text: She lives in a gorgeous house.

11.77.text: And she has a really rewarding career.

14.46.text: And she and her family go

15.67.text:
on all these exciting adventures
together on the weekends.

19.27.text: And I swear that they must take

20.78.text:
a professional photographer
along with them,

24.23.text:
because no matter where they go
or what they do,

26.56.text: the whole family just looks beautiful.

29.50.text:
And she's always posting 
about how blessed she is,

33.27.text:
and how grateful she is
for the life that she has.

36.27.text:
And I get the feeling
that she's not just saying those things

39.18.text:
for the sake of Facebook,
but she truly means it.

43.51.text:
How many of you have a friend
kind of like that?

50.51.text: kind of don't like that person sometimes?

60.75.text:
But that way of thinking 
costs us something.

64.55.text:
And that's what I want to talk
to you about today--

66.96.text: is what our bad habits cost us.

70.88.text:
Maybe you've scrolled through
your Facebook feed

73.22.text:
and you think, "So what
if I roll my eyes?

75.69.text: It's just five seconds of my time.

78.22.text: How could it be hurting me?"

82.25.text: that envying your friends on Facebook,

88.08.text:
That's just one of the traps
that our minds can set for us.

92.02.text: Have you ever complained about your boss?

95.46.text:
Or looked at your friends'
lives and thought,

97.79.text: "Why do they have all the luck?"

100.47.text: You can't help thinking that way, right?

103.03.text:
That way of thinking seems
small in the moment.

105.86.text:
In fact, it might even make you feel
better in the moment.

109.69.text:
But that way of thinking is
eating away at your mental strength.

115.05.text: There's three kinds of destructive beliefs

119.85.text: and rob us of our mental strength.

123.06.text:
The first one is unhealthy
beliefs about ourselves.

127.85.text: We tend to feel sorry for ourselves.

130.72.text:
And while it's OK to be sad
when something bad happens,

136.22.text:
It's when you start
to magnify your misfortune.

140.67.text:
"Why do these things
always have to happen to me?"

143.04.text: "I shouldn't have to deal with it."

145.88.text: That way of thinking keeps you stuck,

147.76.text: keeps you focused on the problem,

149.89.text: keeps you from finding a solution.

153.16.text: And even when you can't create a solution,

155.25.text:
you can always take steps to make
your life or somebody else's life better.

160.65.text:
when you're busy
hosting your own pity party.

165.16.text:
The second type of destructive
belief that holds us back

172.08.text: We think that other people can control us,

174.51.text: and we give away our power.

177.85.text: But as adults who live in a free country,

180.70.text:
there's very few things in life
that you have to do.

184.48.text: So when you say, "I have to work late,"

189.45.text:
Yeah, maybe there will be
consequences if you don't work late,

195.68.text:
Or when you say, "My
mother-in-law drives me crazy,"

202.26.text:
Maybe she's not the nicest 
person on earth,

205.17.text: but it's up to you how you respond to her,

211.42.text:
The third type of unhealthy
belief that holds us back,

215.02.text: is unhealthy beliefs about the world.

218.53.text:
We tend to think that the world
owes us something.

221.29.text: We think, "If I put in enough hard work,

227.08.text:
But expecting success
to fall into your lap

229.26.text: like some sort of cosmic reward,

236.43.text:
But I know it's hard to give up
our bad mental habits.

239.38.text:
It's hard to get rid of those 
unhealthy beliefs

241.63.text:
that we've carried around
with us for so long.

244.73.text: But you can't afford not to give them up.

247.85.text:
Because sooner or later, you're
going to hit a time in your life

251.48.text:
where you need all the mental 
strength that you can muster.

259.07.text: I thought I had life all figured out.

265.16.text: I landed my first big job as a therapist.

269.68.text: And I even bought a house.

271.36.text:
And I thought,
"This is going to be great!"

273.36.text:
"I've got this incredible
jump start on success."

279.50.text: That all changed for me one day

281.46.text: when I got a phone call from my sister.

284.57.text:
She said that our mother
was found unresponsive

287.86.text: and she'd been taken to the hospital.

290.80.text:
My husband Lincoln and I jumped 
in the car and rushed to the hospital.

294.93.text: We couldn't imagine what could be wrong.

299.32.text:
She didn't have any history
of any kind of health problems.

304.43.text: When we got to the hospital,

305.90.text:
doctors explained she'd had
a brain aneurysm.

313.02.text:
who used to wake up in the morning
saying, "It's a great day to be alive,"

319.48.text: That news was devastating to me.

321.23.text: My mother and I had been very close.

323.89.text:
As a therapist, I knew on an intellectual
level how to go through grief.

328.28.text:
But knowing it, and doing it, 
can be two very different things.

332.87.text:
It took a long time before I felt
like I was really healing.

338.21.text:
And then on the three year anniversary
of my mother's death,

344.19.text:
and invited Lincoln and me
to a basketball game.

350.78.text:
at the same auditorium
where I'd last seen my mother,

354.39.text: on the night before she'd passed away.

357.44.text: I hadn't been back there since.

359.49.text: I wasn't even sure I wanted to go back.

361.92.text:
But Lincoln and I talked about it,
and ultimately we said,

365.41.text:
"Maybe that would be a good way
to honor her memory."

368.47.text: So we went to the game.

370.32.text:
And we actually had a really good
time with our friends.

373.49.text: On the drive home that night,

375.17.text: we talked about how great it was

376.71.text:
to finally be able to go
back to that place,

379.06.text: and remember my mother with a smile,

381.25.text: rather than all those feelings of sadness.

385.84.text:
But shortly after we got home that night, 
Lincoln said he didn't feel well.

391.21.text: A few minutes later, he collapsed.

394.55.text: I had to call for an ambulance.

397.85.text: His family met me at the emergency room.

400.63.text: We waited for what seemed like forever,

403.70.text: until finally a doctor came out.

406.70.text:
But rather than taking
us out back to see Lincoln,

409.65.text: he took us back to a private room,

415.27.text: and explained to us that Lincoln,

417.10.text:
who was the most adventurous
person I'd ever met,

423.25.text:
We didn't know at the time, 
but he'd had a heart attack.

428.98.text:
He didn't have any history
of heart problems.

434.03.text: So now I found myself a 26-year-old widow,

437.02.text: and I didn't have my mom.

439.66.text:
I thought, "How am I going
to get through this/"

442.59.text:
And to describe that
as a painful period in my life

447.51.text:
And it was during that time
that I realized

449.68.text:
when you're really going
through tough times,

454.05.text: It only takes one or two small habits

460.02.text: I worked as hard as I could,

461.97.text: not just to create good habits in my life,

464.00.text: but to get rid of those small habits,

466.24.text: no matter how small they might seem.

470.52.text:
I held out hope that someday
life could get better.

477.22.text: A few years down the road, I met Steve.

483.56.text:
We sold the house that
Lincoln and I had lived in,

485.96.text: and we bought a new house, in a new area,

489.16.text: and I got a new job.

492.16.text:
But almost as quickly
as I breathed my sigh of relief

495.10.text: over that fresh start that I had,

497.95.text:
we got the news that Steve's dad
had terminal cancer.

504.18.text:
"Why do these things always
have to keep happening?"

506.61.text:
"Why do I have to keep losing
all my loved ones?"

514.86.text:
it was that that way of thinking
would hold me back.

519.65.text: I knew I was going to need

521.04.text: as much mental strength as I could muster,

523.33.text: to get through one more loss.

526.46.text: So I sat down and I wrote a list

528.53.text:
of all the things mentally
strong people don't do.

532.70.text: And I read over that list.

534.24.text:
It was a reminder of all
of those bad habits

536.80.text:
that I'd done at one time or another, 
that would keep me stuck.

541.10.text:
And I kept reading
that list over and over.

545.42.text: Because within a few weeks of writing it,

552.97.text:
My journey taught me that the secret
to being mentally strong,

557.41.text:
was that you had to give up
your bad mental habits.

561.22.text:
Mental strength is a lot
like physical strength.

564.07.text: If you wanted to be physically strong,

566.56.text:
you'd need to go to the gym
and lift weights.

569.06.text: But if you really wanted to see results,

571.93.text:
you'd also have to give up
eating junk food.

576.38.text: If you want to be mentally strong,

578.23.text:
you need good habits
like practicing gratitude.

581.94.text: But you also have to give up bad habits,

587.27.text: No matter how often that happens,

593.26.text:
So, how do you train
your brain to think differently?

597.28.text: How do you give up those bad mental habits

600.29.text: that you've carried around with you?

603.09.text:
It starts by countering those
unhealthy beliefs that I talked about,

610.75.text:
For example, unhealthy
beliefs about ourselves

613.88.text:
mostly come about because we're 
uncomfortable with our feelings.

617.41.text: Feeling sad, or hurt, or angry, or scared,

622.51.text:
So we go to great lengths
to avoid that discomfort.

628.16.text: by doing things like hosting a pity party.

631.86.text:
And although that's
a temporary distraction,

636.65.text:
The only way to get through 
uncomfortable emotions,

639.63.text:
the only way to deal with them,
is you have to go through them.

642.70.text:
To let yourself feel sad,
and then move on.

646.26.text: To gain confidence in your ability

651.85.text: Unhealthy beliefs about others come about

654.66.text:
because we compare
ourselves to other people.

657.68.text:
We think that they're
either above us or below us.

660.66.text:
Or we think that they can
control how we feel.

662.87.text: Or that we can control how they behave.

665.21.text: Or we blame them for holding us back.

667.91.text:
But really, it's our own
choices that do that.

671.35.text:
You have to accept
that you're your own person,

673.56.text: and other people are separate from you.

676.03.text:
The only person you should
compare yourself to,

678.30.text: is the person that you were yesterday.

682.30.text:
And unhealthy beliefs
about the world come about

685.17.text:
because deep down,
we want the world to be fair.

689.03.text:
We want to think that if we
put in enough good deeds,

692.51.text: enough good things will happen to us.

694.77.text:
Or if we tough it out
through enough bad times,

697.42.text: we'll get some sort of reward.

700.42.text:
But ultimately you have
to accept that life isn't fair.

706.55.text:
Yeah, it means you won't necessarily
be rewarded for your goodness,

710.08.text:
but it also means no matter
how much you've suffered,

712.86.text: you're not doomed to keep suffering.

716.50.text: The world doesn't work that way.

719.20.text: Your world is what you make it.

722.64.text:
But of course before you
can change your world,

725.02.text:
you have to believe
that you can change it.

728.85.text:
I once worked with this man
who had been diabetic for years.

733.24.text: His doctor referred him to therapy

735.45.text: because he had some bad mental habits

737.72.text:
that were starting to affect
his physical health.

741.18.text:
His mother had died from complications
of diabetes at a young age,

745.24.text: so he just believed he was doomed,

747.69.text:
and he'd given up trying to manage
his blood sugar altogether.

751.83.text:
In fact, his blood sugar
had gotten so high lately,

754.79.text: that it was starting to affect his vision.

757.38.text:
And he had his driver's
license taken away.

764.13.text: When he came into my office, it was clear

766.49.text:
he knew all the things
he could do to manage his blood sugar.

770.20.text:
He just didn't think
it was worth the effort.

774.22.text:
But eventually, he agreed
to make one small change.

778.91.text:
He said, "I'll give up
my two liter-a-day Pepsi habit,

782.32.text: and I'll trade it in for Diet Pepsi."

785.14.text:
And he couldn't believe how quickly
his numbers started to improve.

790.63.text: And even though he came every week

792.46.text:
to remind me how horrible
Diet Pepsi tasted,

799.57.text:
And once he started to see
a little bit of improvement,

802.18.text:
he said, "Well, maybe I could
look at some of my other habits."

805.93.text:
He said, "I could trade in
my nightly bowl of ice cream

808.94.text: for a snack with a little less sugar."

812.18.text:
And then one day he was at a thrift
store with some friends,

815.78.text:
and he found this beat-up
old exercise bike.

818.68.text: He bought it for a couple of bucks,

820.72.text:
and he brought it home,
and he parked it in front of his TV.

825.42.text:
while he'd watch some
of his favorite shows every night.

829.48.text: And not only did he lose weight,

831.78.text:
but one day, he noticed
he could see the TV

835.59.text:
just a little bit more clearly
than he had before.

839.78.text: And suddenly it occurred to him,

841.88.text:
maybe the damage done
to his eyesight wasn't permanent.

846.64.text: So he set a new goal for himself--

848.33.text: to get his driver's license back.

851.24.text: And from that day forward, he was on fire.

854.71.text:
By the end of our time together,
he was coming in every week

857.58.text:
saying, "OK, what are we
going to do this week?"

861.02.text:
Because he finally believed
that he could change his world.

864.54.text:
And that he had the mental
strength to change it.

867.80.text:
And that he could give up
his bad mental habits.

870.33.text:
And it all started
with just one small step.

875.68.text: So I invite you to consider

877.68.text:
what bad mental habits
are holding you back?

883.17.text:
are keeping you from being
as mentally strong as you could be?

887.88.text:
And what is one small step
that you could take today?
